segments.text: This is an interview with John Ragland, Sr. by Mark McCall on April 29, 1993 at Westminster Presbyterian Church concerning the perspectives of the Civil Rights Movement during the 1960s.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I'm asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection at the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
Yes, it is.
What is your current job and profession?
I am a senior minister at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Bryan, Texas.
And where were you born?
I was born in Jacksonville, Florida.
Do you want to know the date?
Sure.
That doesn't bother me.
It was April 6, 1947.
And where did you grow up?
I grew up in the southeast.
major cities in the southeast.
Jacksonville, Florida, Daytona, Pensacola, Savannah, Atlanta, Georgia, Charlotte, North Carolina, Birmingham, Alabama, Jackson, Mississippi.
When were you in high school?
I was in high school from about 1961 to 1965.
How did you perceive the situations in America toward minorities?
Well, I was in high school in Atlanta, Georgia.
And I lived in Atlanta two different times.
I lived in Atlanta in the mid-50s when I was probably in the fourth grade.
And then we came back in the early 60s when I was in the 10th grade.
And so I guess it wasn't 61 or 65.
I guess it was really 62 to 65 is when I was really
Well, 61, 65, anyway, something like that.
Because I was there when Sean Kennedy was assassinated.
When was that?
Was that in 61 or 62?
Right in there.
Right, right.
Well, I do remember in the mid-50s, I could go into the richest apartment store in downtown Atlanta.
And I was getting ready to go in.
Went down to the basement.
I was going to go to the bathroom.
And I really wasn't paying attention to what I was doing.
And I started walking into this bathroom, and this policeman stopped me.
And he said, you can't go in that bathroom.
That bathroom is for, I guess he said, Negroes.
And you need to go to this bathroom, because this is for whites.
And I can also remember that there, in the bus station, there was a section for black people and there was a section for white people.
I think in the high school years, I don't have any real recollections of any of that, one way or the other.
It's just not in my mind.
And our high school was not integrating any sense of the word when I was in high school.
Why did you decide to go into the ministry?
Well, I was headed for really a military career.
I had enjoyed the ROTC program in high school immensely, and I thought I would really enjoy a military career.
And then I became a Christian, came to know Christ as my personal Savior and Lord about the summer before my senior year.
God began to change some of my motivations and really began to put within me a desire to pursue a full-time Christian vocational work such as ministry.
I started moving in that direction.
Where'd you go?
Where'd you attend college, seminary?
I went to Belhaven College, which is a four-year liberal arts college related to the Presbyterian Church.
At that time, it was related to the Presbyterian Church in the United States, which was the old Southern Presbyterian Church.
And then I went to seminary, Reformed Theological Seminary, also in Jackson, Mississippi.
During what years?
Okay, I was at Belle Haven from 1965 to 1969, and I performed seminary from 1969 until 1973, and I took a year out and served the church in Prattville, Alabama.
Okay, can you describe Belle Haven during the 60s?
What was it?
Just some...
Oral descriptions, I guess, of the school?
Okay, well, Belhaven was not, there were no black students in Belhaven College until my senior year.
And at that time, I think we had one student.
She ended up, I think she ended up graduating.
She must have transferred in.
There, the college was a small school.
And I think the college somewhat reflected the conflict over race relations, attitudes toward race relations in society in general.
What I'm meaning by that is you had some people that really didn't
agree with a prejudiced attitude toward black people whatsoever.
Some were from missionary families, either from Africa or from Brazil.
And they just didn't compute in their thinking to have that kind of attitude toward black people.
Then you had some other people that were, that was what they were brought up with.
That was their cultural perspective.
So there was somewhat of a conflict during that, from about 1965 all the way to 69.
In Belle Haven I remember that there were somewhat of a
somewhat of a tension there among some of the students.

And Belhaven itself went through a transition as they moved from a, I think they adopted a policy, debated it extensively, but they finally, I think the board adopted basically a policy of not discriminating on the basis of race or color.
I think part of that was
in with the getting federal money.
And then there were some that didn't even want to be getting federal money.
It didn't really have anything to do with the race at all.
It was just a philosophy of receiving federal funds.
So some of that debate was quite mixed.
But some of it did deal with the issue of integration.
Where did most of the students come from?
I think most of the students really came from the South.
Was it a close campus between the student to student?
Oh, yeah.
It was a very small campus.
And between the faculty and the students?
Yes, close relationship between faculty and students.
Very good faculty-student ratio.
Remember you telling how the faculty used to come or want some, there was a couple of guys that used to come around before finals.
They kind of breezed in to kind of give a word of encouragement, which is really appreciated.
That was in the Bible department primarily.
I think they really had a pastoral concern for students.
And was it co-ed at the time?
Yep, it was co-ed.
We already touched on this a little bit, but were there any black students?
Not until my senior year.
How did you feel about the black students or what you really, but black race during your freshman year?
Well, I don't know.
I think I was going through something of a transition.
I think my freshman year, it was either my freshman year or my sophomore year, I sensed that it was my freshman year.
There was a fellow there that was from Alabama.
I don't want to mention his name, but he was from Alabama.
He was a Christian student.
And we had in Jackson at that time a showing of the Billy Graham film, which was called The Restless Ones.
And it was shown at the Mississippi State Coliseum.
That's where they have the state fair.
And this young man, with all the innocence in the world,
with a genuine concern to reach out, he invited a black girl to go with him to this Billy Graham crusade.
And his interest was that he really wanted to hear what was going on.
Or if she was already Christian, he wanted her to find out about the film.
He took her.
And I can remember that, and this is all tied in with your question, so don't worry about it.
I haven't forgotten your question.
But this student went ahead and took her on to that film, and then later that afternoon,
I think it was after dinner, and it was, you know, the afternoon.
It's daylight for longer than usual.
We had, I think, kind of a devotions of some sort out on the steps of one of the buildings there.
And right in the middle of that, someone came up and announced that a bunch of the basketball players
were after this student from Alabama.
And so a couple of guys took off to go find out what was going on.
And then I kind of got some of the information.
And what we found out was that these basketball players, a number of them from Mississippi, a number of them from Louisiana,
were outraged, this guy would take a black group to this Billy Graham.
And they were out to beat him up for doing it.
And so these other guys took off to go try to protect him.
So I took off to go find out what in the world was going on.
And I remember we were up on the third floor of Wells Hall, as it was called.
It was grim, because I was on one end of it, and all the basketball players were on the other end, standing outside of this young man's locked dorm door.
He was inside, hiding for his life.
And these guys were outside, and they were ready to take him apart.
And about that time, the coach came over there, and he kind of cleared him out of it.
He wasn't very happy with it.

with her attitude, but neither was he very happy with what that student did, because he was from Louisiana, and reflected some of those very attitudes himself, and was himself in no way at that time had come to know Christ in his life, and basically was being dominated by a sinful and self-centered godless perspective.
Now for myself, I think
something of my pilgrimage in working through race relationships, I think I had been working through some things.
I think the early civil rights movement and all this discussion about race relations had prompted me, since I've been a Christian, to be thinking through my own attitude.
In fact, I remember when I was very young,
and lived in Atlanta, that I was, I remember saying, yes sir, to a black man, and I was reprimanded for doing that.
You don't do that.
You don't say, ma'am, or sir, to a black man.
And so, I myself was a product of southern, a certain aspect of old south culture.
But I was, I had become a Christian.
And so I had, that
So I began to think through, as a Christian, what should my attitude be toward black people and race relationships?

And I can remember specifically sitting down and reading in the first chapter, no, second chapter of James, where James is rebuking the discriminatory attitude that had grown up among some of the Christians that he was writing to concerning

the rich and poor where they bring the rich in and put them up at the front and they sit the poor back and then James said that's a wrong attitude that you have because he goes on to say God is not a respecter of persons and when I read that I was convicted I said here's my answer here's what my attitude is toward people toward black people toward people that are not like me
they're the image of God, and I need to relate to them in a loving way, and relate to them as I would want to be related to, and so forth and so on.
And I really think that the grace of God in my heart, plus the wisdom of God according to the Scripture and His directions for my life, worked in me to begin to make some changes in my evidence.
So I think by the time that happened to that young man from Alabama, my attitudes were already beginning to change.
And that was toward, it would have been in the spring, probably freshman year.
Just kind of aside, are the basketball players, were they recruited?
Or were they just taken from the student population?
They were recruited.
And how much...
Was it a strict Christian school?
What was the ratio?
I don't really want to put a ratio on it, but it's a liberal arts college.
What was associated with the church?
What you're really asking is how Christian was this Christian college?
And I would have to say that it was, while everybody on the faculty was required to make some kind of Christian assent, it was certainly debatable whether we were dealing with

evangelical Christians, and what I mean by evangelical Christian is a person that believes that Christ's death on the cross was a vicarious atonement, a substitutionary atonement, was paying for the sins of sinners, and that through faith along with Christ we are forgiven for our sins, and believe in the scriptures being inerrant in its original communication, and then protected in its scripturation.
and protected in its transmission, not everyone on the faculty would have fit that description.
And certainly not everybody in the student body fit that description.

We had some students who came from Christian homes who were the most rebellious people you'd ever seen in your life because they didn't want to be there, the music didn't need to be there, and they weren't happy about it at all.
So, and then you had some people that were genuine laborers and you had some faculty who were genuine laborers.
So, how many, I guess, you kind of split up in like cliques or whatever, groups, and how many people overall would you say the enrollment was about?
About 600.
About 600.

About how many general groups, I guess, or how many general conflicts probably were there as far as, like you have your Christians on one side or your Evangelicals, and then was there a wide spectrum of varying opinions?
Well, you had different groups.
Your largest group, religious group, was probably called Westminster Fellowship, and that was predominantly a Presbyterian group.

kind of fellowship that we'd meet in a large group meeting on a Thursday night and we'd fill up the science lecture hall and probably have anywhere from 100 to maybe 150 packed in there and have a good meeting.
Then you had some Methodist and some Baptist and some Lutherans.
And then you had a number of students who really didn't make any noise about being Christians.
But I would have to say it was predominantly Christians with a minority of non-Christians as far as the student body was concerned.
Were there any incidents or demonstrations while you were at Belhaven?
outside of like in the community, involved in the community?
No, not in the big city of Jackson.
Of course, I think it was during that period of time that Martin Luther King was assassinated and there were the riots all over the country.
I just don't really remember when those three civil rights workers were killed in Philadelphia, Mississippi.
by those plane folks.
I can't remember when that was before I came to Belle Haven.
It seems like it was a while ago.
Was there a lot of...
Was there a lot of civil unrest for Lillian Jackson as a whole?
I don't really remember a lot of it.
How did the views on campus change when you were there?
Well, it's interesting.
I think that there was
growth in understanding the implications of the scripture for race relationships.
The Presbyterian Church in Mississippi itself was working through those very issues.
And you have, it's very interesting, you had liberals, and when I say liberal, that would be somebody that would
reject the Bible as really being divinely inspired without error from beginning to end.
And someone that would reject miracles of Christ or explain them in a naturalistic sort of way.
But primarily it would be a rejection of Scripture as being divinely inspired.
inspired without AR from beginning to end in the original manuscripts.
I would define that person as liberal.
And there were those liberals in the Southern Presbyterian Church in Mississippi.
And they were very social action oriented.
Their gospel was what we call a social gospel.
They talked in terms of
of redeeming society and redeeming the institutions of society.
And so the Civil Rights Movement was a big thing for them.
I mean, that was where it's at.
Down in Mississippi, man, they were going to integrate all the churches, and integration's what we're going to have to do.
So that was kind of it.
banner which they marched under.
Then you had other, what, then you had other, you had primarily lay people in Mississippi that were in the Southern Presbyterian Church who resisted that tremendously.
And many of these were, quote, conservatives.
And I'm going to say they were conservative in the sense that they were politically conservative.
And conservative in the sense that they wanted to conserve certainly the cultural position that they were taking when it came to the matter of segregation and integration.
And they were also religiously conservative in the sense that they accepted
historic biblical Christianity and the teaching about Christ and His work as Savior, and they accepted the Bible as the Word of God in the fullest sense of the word.
But not all of them had a genuine living faith relationship to Christ.
It was more cultural than it was real, although there were some that it was very real in.
And then you had ministers who were definitely conservative, but who understood the implications of scripture for race relations.
And they recognized the segregation and prejudice toward black people because they're black was really an expression of sin.
And so they were...
They were in an interesting position.
And they were having to be sensitive to the people that needed to be led.
At the same time, they needed to be sensitive to the wrong foundation that the liberal ministers were operating with.
And so they had a delicate road to walk during the 60s in Mississippi as they sought to lead the church
and to lead these conservative lay people into really embracing a biblical position in obedience to Christ and to really move forward.
And they made some strides.
They made some strides in that.
And some of those men were in the Bible department, but they didn't come.
And so they also had some impact and influence on the student body in their own perspectives about this.
So the strides that have been made in the church in Mississippi when it comes to race relations, where it's been among the conservative Presbyterian church,
the ministers have led the way.
During this time, it would have been possible to say Martin Luther King or another prominent black activist would have been welcome to give the commencement speech.
Absolutely not.
He would not have been welcome.
Now, with Martin Luther King, it's interesting.
You've got a...
I remember the Selma March.
And I remember my attitude toward that was extremely negative.
And the sit-ins and all the things that they did and the bus-ins that they did, they're very negative attitude toward us.
And it's negative because of the so-called civil disobedience.
And civil disobedience is not civil.
It's disobedience.
It's breaking the law.
And that's not to say that the laws are just.
I think they were unjust laws.
I don't think there's any question of that.
But at the same time, I don't think two wrongs make a right.
And the disdain for law that was represented in that movement, I really didn't appreciate.
And still don't appreciate.
But I do think
that God used that, and he brought about some changes which are really good changes in one sense of the word.
But you see, the problem with the Civil Rights Movement is, and I think we're seeing this in the 90s, that the Civil Rights Movement dealt with externals, but was unable to address the internals.
And that's the changing of people's attitudes.
You've got people who have begrudgingly accepted non-discrimination in terms of outward behavior, while inside their hearts the same old discrimination lives on.
And I really believe it takes the teaching of the Scripture and the grace of God in Christ to begin to make those kind of changes in hearts.
And those kind of changes in the heart that have been made, there have been perverts in Mississippi.
They've got a long ways to go.
But there has been some change in heart attitudes, and it has come through the gospel.
It hasn't come through legislation and those changes.
Although I think, while I don't appreciate it, in the sense that I think that was the right thing to do,
I think today, 25, 30 years later, I have a much better appreciation of where they were coming from, the frustration they felt, the sense of injustice that they felt.
And certainly, to be treated as second-class people and to be treated as non-people, it does insult everyone's humanity.
And I can appreciate and understand
where they were coming from, though I don't appreciate the math that they were working with to try to make the changes they made.
To get back to your original question about the, we would have, quote, liberal speakers come and speak at chapel.
I remember William Winter
who came and spoke in chapel.
William Winter was at one time governor of Mississippi.
He was more of a moderate to liberal governor, politically speaking.
He came and spoke.
I think at one time he may have even been on the board of Bellarmine College because he was a Presbyterian.
He represented more of that liberal wing of the Presbyterian church in Mississippi.
He came and spoke and so forth.
But I think much beyond that, to have, back when I was there, to have a plaque to come and speak would have been, in a circumstance like Martin Luther King, would not have been appreciated.
What was taught at Bill Haven concerning black citizens?
You know, as well as far as in class, you know, maybe just... Well, there certainly was not racism when the issues were addressed.
And in fact, I remember I did a...
a paper on race relations for one of my Bible classes.
And I remember the title of my paper was Race Relations, Not a Black or White Issue.
And I remember the professor saying that was a very cool pun in the title.

But my impression is that as far as instruction was concerned, that we had men, and primarily where this was coming from, of course the Mount Major was bombed, so I really can't speak for the other departments, but I would say that the Bible department, when we would touch on these issues, they were really moving us toward a
God would put out a biblical perspective recognizing the image-bearing nature of all of us and the need for us to deal with them as we would discriminate against them because they're different.
Q This gets in a little bit about seminary a little bit later, but even while you were at Westminster, how was a prospective minister?
Was there a set way?
A When I was at Belhaven?
Q Well, at Belhaven, and also when you were at the seminary.
A Reform seminary?
Q Right.
How was your training here to become a minister?
How were you?
Was there any certain way that you were supposed to view it, or was it really a personal matter?
Well, I don't know that that was, you know, there was an over, we didn't have any classes on race relationships or anything like that.
We didn't have any classes on multiculturalism and so-called desensitizing you to this and that kind of stuff we're getting now in the 90s in which we're having to address the very real problem that

changing legislation does not change human hearts and we're now finding this out but the I do remember as I was in seminary that I should mention this let me mention this this would fold into this in my between my my
My senior year in college and my seminary, after I graduated from college, I worked at Briarwood Presbyterian Church, and I'd also worked there the summer before.
Briarwood is in Birmingham, Alabama.
It's an evangelical church.
It was a southern Presbyterian church back in 68, 69, later came into the PCA, helped to form the PCA, Presbyterian Church of America.
And it was a conservative church, and one of those churches where they were really seeking to follow the scripture, and really seeking to follow the scripture when the race was launched.
And they began a program called Operation, it was called Camp New Face.
in which there was a concerted effort to minister to inner-city black children and to take them out at the expense of Rarwoos Christian Church to a camp.
It was a Presbytery camp.
Presbytery is our way of...
It's kind of like a Baptist...
association.
It's an association, a connected association of Presbyterian churches in given areas called Presbyterian.
And Presbyterian Birmingham had a camp.
And Briarwood was a member of that Presbyterian.
So we used that camp, the Birmingham Presbyterian camp.
And we took some black kids out there to that camp.
And these were, we had little kids, and I worked with that camp.
Man, it was a tremendous experience.
Just a tremendous experience.
I remember that was back when Hubert Humphrey was running against Richard Nixon.
And we had a black camp director.
I remember getting into a little discussion with him, and he was a hunter supporter, and I was in things as a supporter.
We were talking about who could really help out the black people the most.
It was really a very enlightening, great time in my life.
I made some great friends.
I had some black parents who were really wonderful experiences.
But once again, we see it is the Episcopal Church that was really leading there in ministry, not just the outward conduct, but really seeking the ministry of the Father.
So I think there was a growing conviction in me that...

that a segregationist attitude comes to the church, an attitude of, we won't let black people come and worship in our churches, one that I couldn't tolerate to the point that I remember when I graduated as a senior and was looking at churches, that one of my questions that I would ask was, what is your attitude toward black people in this church?
So whatever was contributing to that, there were a lot of things contributing to that.
Running the board is working my life and just lots of things.
But it wasn't a case of seminary, you know, sitting in a stand and saying, here's the attitude you want me to take.
How are...
In the early 60s, there was a book written by a black like me, by John Howard Griffin, where he went through, traveled through the South, and appeared as both a black person and as a white person.
And later on in the experiment, he would go through town as a black person to be treated one way by the black people, and then go back through as a white person.
and the black people would just disdain and everything and wouldn't have anything to do with it.
How were the black attitudes, the black children, counselors, and other people?
You know, that was really interesting.
That's a good question.
My experience with that was that the high school guys were woke.
I took an authoritarian approach to my discipline with them.
In the cabin, for example, I'd say, okay, let's get your beds made.
They wouldn't be doing it.
I'd say, okay, I want you all to go.
I want you to get down and do ten push-ups.
And that guy just fell on the bed and was laughing at me.
I said, whoa, what are we going to do here?
There was no respect or authority whatsoever.
In fact, I remember in that camp, the camp broke out into a great big fight.
And I was very thankful that we had...
a wrestler on staff that was from the University of Michigan.
And he was a big old guy, and he just waded into the group and grabbed about five of them and pulled them out.
And, well, I was glad to see him around.
But that's kind of a scary thing.
But with the little kids, the kids, you know, like maybe middler age, maybe 5th grade, 6th grade, 4th, 5th, 6th, all they would do.
And God has really done some tremendous work in their mind.
Father was there.
And it was a tremendous time, just a tremendous time.
A number of kids really came to know the Savior and had experience.
So that's the way I see it.
The older they got, they seemed to get more burdened, more of a, which I guess would be true with white kids.
You need kids, I mean all sorts of kids.
That's just kind of the way it is across the board.
Does that kind of get you to your question?
How many on staff there, how many counselors were funded in Cape Town?
Now when you say that.
At Bellhaven?
Well, Bellhaven and Camp.
Camp New Face?
Yeah.
Oh, I think all of them.
Okay.
Unless it was the... No, I think they're all from this town.
How about Bellhaven?
Are there any students from up north?
Very.
Were the students... During this time, there's also a big campus...
you know, students' free speech movement on campuses across America and Berkeley, California and everything is going on.
How was that treated at Belhaven?
Well, it kind of emerged a little bit at Belhaven.
You know, I was in the middle of Vietnam as well and I remember our
I think it was the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution.
I think our Student Government Association, SGA, voted a resolution disapproving of the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution.
And I think that there was unrest with respect to the administration.
I remember the closest thing we ever got to a riot on campus.
All the students gathered into the
into the cafeteria, and we were really upset about some things.
I don't remember exactly what it was, but I remember the president, Howard J. Cleveland, at the time, he came in and addressed everybody.
But there was something of an angry spirit, kind of an angry atmosphere.
Were you all fairly free to discuss
The Civil Rights Movement?
Oh, sure.
On to a little bit about PCA, history of PCA a little bit.
What was the doctrine of the church?
Was there an official?
The church really didn't take any kind of official position on this question.
The old Southern Presbyterian Church did adopt

a change in their book church order which specifically says that churches will not discriminate on race or color when it comes to membership in the church and in the when the pca was in 1973 there were
Some of the churches that helped form the BCNA were segregationist churches.
They were churches that...
So you had some churches that were segregationist churches.
In fact, maybe even some churches that had policies
people being allowed to come into their churches.
And of course, we had Trinity Presbyterian Church that was in Montgomery, Alabama.
That was a very famous church.
The Supreme Court Justice, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Alabama was a member of that congregation.

And I think it was back in the 1960s that the pastor then, who was Robert Strong, stood out in front of the church with all the news there and all the cameras and black people coming up and making a point there in Montgomery about this segregationist church.
And the pastor graciously saying, you will not be permitted to come worship here.
That church came into the PCA.
In fact, that church was one of the founding churches of the PCA.
Then you got Briarwood.
You got Briarwood taking a very different perspective on it.
Briarwood was receiving black members and blacks into membership and leading a different approach there.
you've got i would say in the dca day probably you've got pockets pockets very small very much where you would have these would be old old established churches in some parts of the south that still
holding on to some remnants, although I don't know of any churches that have any kind of official policies about closed-door policies.
I think maybe all of those are gone.
But there may still be some attitudes, a hardening of the attitude that is still hanging on.
So I would say that the overwhelming, the overwhelming
Your position certainly reflects my position.
Like here at Westminster, I mean, it's not even an issue.
I mean, we have black, we have Indian, we have Korean, we have, you know, we're here to minister to all the people in this town.
and we're we're out here reaching wherever the lord gives us an opportunity to reach i think the gospel has made that possible the gospel
I think the ease with which we deal with this is because we are a diverse congregation.
We don't necessarily reflect a predominantly Old South cultural perspective, although I think there is certainly a number of people in the Old South that are members of the congregation.
I think that has helped make that easier to deal with.
I think in, you know, there, like in Briarwood,
There were some things they had to work through, some tensions they had to work through, but they had to work them through very successfully.
So, you know, as far as the PCA is concerned, we are far less of a segregationist kind of group in 1993 than we were in 1970.
When was the PCA formed?
And it was formed primarily by churches that came out of the old southern Presbyterian church.
You had a mixture there.
You had some, in memory I was talking about, you had those conservatives who were in Mississippi that were segregationist oriented and then you had
And then you had conservatives who were saying, no, we need to... That's really not consistent with the scriptural approach.
And I think you had some of that mixture that came into the piece of that.
Although I think the dominant... the dominant position would have been those conservatives that would say segregation needs to go.
It's not scriptural.
Were there any... Was it...
Primarily the southern churches?
Primarily southern churches.
Were there any northern churches?
In about 1983, the Reformed Presbyterian Church, which is primarily northern, united with the PCM.
So we're much more of a national church than we were.
How would you say that the...
Overall, the events, the civil rights movement and everything going on, how did that affect your education?
Is there anything else?
Well, I think, I would say that it didn't affect my education.

because I got out of public school before all the upheaval of integrating all those schools came in, which had a, I think, from a pedagogical point of view, a devastating effect on the education of blacks and whites.
I think trying to mix social engineering in
with pedagogy was disastrous.
There should have been.
The busing, the whole busing thing, it was terribly chaotic, terribly chaotic.
So how would you,
How would you have fixed it, so to say?
Well, how would I have fixed it?
That's a really good question.
I think I might have been more gradual than revolutionary.
I think I might have wanted to start at the lowest grades and face it.
I would...

I would have wanted to bring in the influence of the church, and here particularly I would think the conservative church that is preaching the gospel, but also is really preaching a biblical view of the relations of the races.
And have sought to bring them in as allies to help them work with adults, to work with parents, to help them work through these issues.
